Moreover that hee had drawne a Publicacion which if it were liked, desired that it might be putt in printe beinge for the entertaynment of good and sufficient Laborers and Husbandmen, Artificers and manuall Trades to be sett outt att the time formerly specified vnto the Publique and Colledg Land which beinge read and putt to the question was ratyfied by erection of hands.

After this hee signified that accordinge to the desire of the last Courte hee had beene with Mr. Secretary Calvert and delivered the Companies answere touchinge the Transporting of men prest by his Maty which gaue nott full satisfaccon for that the Kings desyre admitted no delaies butt forthwith to have 50 of the 100 shipt away with all speed, Notwithstanding the many inconvenyences which Mr. Thier alleadged would therby acerew vnto the Company that they could not goe in lesse then fower Shipps, for feare they beinge many togeather may drawe more vnto them and so muteny and carry away the Ships, which would stand the Company in fowre thousand poundes, and they not suddenly to be gotten att this time of the yeare, butt all not servinge the turne hee tolde them what a pinch hee was putt vnto and therfore desyred their Counsell and Advise.

Wheruppon divers waise beinge thought on and considered, the Court could finde no fitter nor more satisfactory answere then this; That the Company would be att the charge to maynteyne them till ther be shippinge provyded, if so be they were commaunded to doe it.

And therefore have appointed a Committee of select Merchants to employ their whole endeavours for the Compassing of Shipping with all speed possible; Namely, Mr. Deputy Ferrar, Mr. Keightley, Mr. Wiseman, Mr. Cranmore, Mr. Bull, Mr. Sheppard, and Mr. Mellinge and to that end Mr. Thier was content the Eight hundred pounds Adventured by the general Stocke in the Magazine should remain there to be employed to these uses from time to time, wherunto if they pleased there should be two hundred pounds more added out of the Cash in his Custody, which Thousand pounds to be only for the satisfying of his Majesty's desires from time to time. If the North Colony abridge them of this, they would take away their means and encouragement of sending of men. Unto which Sir Ferdinando Gorges replied that if he mistake not himself both the Companies were limited by the Patent unto which he would submit himself, for the deciding whereof it is referred unto the Council who are of both Companies to examine the letters Patents tomorrow afternoon at my Lord of Southampton's and accordingly to determine the Dispute.

Whervppon Mr Deputy acquainted the Courte for accomodatinge all to Acquaint Mr Webb wth the nomber they send, that if any pticuler Adventurer would send ouer men to Virginia let him give notice of the nomber therof to William Webb the husband and pay vnto him six pounds for their passage Shippinge should be provided for them wth the Companies men.

And because himselfe and the Comittees will have more then enough for the furnishing to provide all things necessary and sufficient against that time of sendinge their people away hee desyred that every one of the Company would give their helpinge hand for the furnishing them wth good and able men for this voyadge, and to take such care and paines in itt as if itt were for their owne pryvate prayinge all men to take notice of his request.

And forasmuch as by the orders of this Courte the Lotteries are now to dissolve that therefore they would consider of some course for the defraying of future charge or else continue them halfe a year longer, Wherevpon finding no other means as yet to accrew unto the Company, It was ordered they should last till midsomer next. and being put to the question was confirmed by erection of hands. Further Mr. Treasurer made knowne that hee had received a verie favour- able letter from the Lord Arch Bishop of Yorke that if hee will send more briefs there shall be new Collections, As also how much the Company was beholdinge to the Dyocess of London, my Lord Bishop having sent in a full Thousand pounds, As also that Mr. Register demandeth 20£ which hee saith the Company promised him for his London paynes. which the Courte thinks him very worthy of, and therefore have agreed that hee shall have the said some of xx£ paid unto him out of such monneys as shall come to him or is yett remayninge in his Custodie.

488:
A Day of Humiliation.

Heuer since the late and lamentable Fire of London, which hath consumed the greatest part of the City, and the most considerable part of the Trade of this Nation, hath there been a more solemn day of Humiliation, then this day is appointed to be. It is a day wherein the Lord hath called us to humble our selves before him, and to seek his face, that he may turn away his wrath from us, and restore us to our former prosperity. The Lord hath smitten us with a sore stroke, and hath laid us low in the dust; and now he calls upon us to return unto him with weeping and with mourning, and to seek his face, that he may have mercy upon us, and heal our land. Let us therefore humble our selves before the Lord this day, and seek his face, that he may turn away his wrath from us, and restore us to our former prosperity. Let us confess our sins, and forsake them, and turn unto the Lord with all our hearts, that he may have mercy upon us, and heal our land. Let us pray for the peace of Jerusalem, and for the prosperity of our Nation, that the Lord may bless us, and make us a blessing to the Nations round about us. Let us pray for the King, and for all that are in authority, that the Lord may give them wisdom and understanding, to govern this Nation in the fear of the Lord, and to seek the peace and prosperity thereof. Let us pray for the Ministers of the Gospel, that the Lord may bless their labours, and make them successful in turning many to righteousness. Let us pray for the poor and needy, that the Lord may provide for them, and supply all their wants. Let us pray for the sick and afflicted, that the Lord may heal them, and comfort them in all their troubles. Let us pray for the Churches of Christ, that the Lord may bless them, and make them fruitful in every good work. Let us pray for the conversion of the Jews, and for the calling in of the Gentiles, that the Lord may hasten the coming of his Kingdom, and the glory of his Church. Let us pray for the peace of the world, that the Lord may make wars to cease, and establish his Kingdom of righteousness and peace. Let us pray for the outpouring of the Spirit upon all flesh, that the Lord may revive his work, and make his Church a praise in the earth. Let us pray for the coming of the Lord Jesus, that he may come quickly, and take to himself his great power, and reign. Let us pray for the grace of God, that we may be found in him, not having our own righteousness, but the righteousness which is of God by faith. Let us pray for the love of God, that we may love him with all our hearts, and our neighbours as ourselves. Let us pray for the peace of God, that it may rule in our hearts, and keep us in perfect peace. Let us pray for the joy of the Lord, that it may be our strength, and our song in the house of our pilgrimage. Let us pray for the hope of glory, that it may purify us, and make us meet for the inheritance of the saints in light. Let us pray for the faith of God's elect, that it may work by love, and overcome the world. Let us pray for the patience of the saints, that we may endure to the end, and receive the crown of life. Let us pray for the wisdom that is from above, that it may guide us in all our ways, and make us wise unto salvation. Let us pray for the power of God, that it may strengthen us with all might, according to his glorious power, unto all patience and long-suffering with joyfulness. Let us pray for the presence of God, that it may be with us always, even unto the end of the world. Let us pray for the blessing of God, that it may be upon us, and upon our children, and upon our children's children, unto the third and fourth generation. Let us pray for the glory of God, that it may fill the earth, as the waters cover the sea. Let us pray for the Kingdom of God, that it may come, and his will be done on earth, as it is in heaven. Let us pray for the name of God, that it may be hallowed, and his praise be glorious in all the earth. Let us pray for the work of God, that it may prosper in our hands, and his Kingdom be established in righteousness and peace. Let us pray for the word of God, that it may dwell in us richly, in all wisdom and spiritual understanding. Sir Edwin Sandys

It was ordered in the last Courte repayringe the next day to the Councell Table presented a Petition to their Lo: accordinge as it was referred vnto him in the name of the Councell and Company in wch was conteyned the whole State of the busines, Mr. Iacobb beinge there, it pleased their Lo: to give them moste honorable audience hearinge the allegacons of both sides. Where Mr. Attorney generall delivered his cleere opinion to the LL: That the Company by their Pattent were free from Imposition; And in fine it was ordered by their Lo: that the said Mr. Iacobb should deliver the said Tobacco vnto them paying all other Duties that might appteyne therevnto, wch was submitted to their Lo: Iudgments; Therfor he moved that the Petition togeather wth their Lo: order might be entred in the Courte Booke wch was well liked of: being as followeth.

To ye Ri: Hono: the LL: and others of his Ma: most Honorable Privie Councell

The humble Petition of ye Threr Counsell and Company for Virginia

Humbly shew vnto yo: Lo: Whereas the Plantacon of Virginia by reason of many great difficulties hath beene and still is a matter of excessive charge to the pticular Adventurers, And if it please God to prosper the same so as it be brought to perfection (whereof the hope is now greater then heretofore at any time) It wilbe a matter not onely of strength and honour but also of great profit to his Ma: and his people And to his Ma pticulerly in his Customs, unto wch the negotiacon established wth Virginia will raise a cleere and in short time a great addition, as growinge by mutuall Traffique betweene the English and English, who now yearly remove thither in very great multitudes: [55] In wch and many other important Considerations it pleased his most excellent Ma: of his Princely benegnity by his Tres Pattents bearinge date the 23rd of May in the Seaventh year of his Raigne of England &c. To graunt vnto the said Company freedome from Custome and Subsedie in Virginia for one and Twenty years and in England for a certaine number of years now expired. and from all other Taxes and Impositions for ever. ** Exceptinge onely the thue

**pounds p Centi: due for Custome vppon all such goods and Marchandizes as shalbe brought or Imported into this Realme of England or any other his Maᵗ: Dominions accordinge to the Ancient Trade of Marchants.” And the like graunt hath beene made by his Maᵗ: to yᵉ Compᵗ of yᵉ Somer Ilands by his gracious tres Pattents bearinge date the 29ᵗʰ of Iune in the 13ᵗʰ yeare of his Raigne of England Cᵗ save that the freedome from Custome and Subsydie graunted to them is not yett expired. Which Compᵗ of the Somer lands are all members of the Virginia Company and for the mutuall strength of both parties are soe to continue. All wᶜʰ notwithstandinge the flarmoᵘʳ of his Maᵗ: Customs by a generall rate made of Tobacco att xᵗ the pound in regard the Spanish Tobacco is worth much more though the Virginia Tobacco give not halfe so much, demaund of yor Supplyants vjᵈ the pound for their Virginia Tobacco wᶜʰ they humbly desire may be rated att a iust valew by itt selfe (wᶜʰ they shall willingly pay) and not raysed to the double by cooplinge itt wᵗʰ the Spanish wᶜʰ is sould ordinaryly att 18ᵈ the pound and some times att more. They Complaine allso to your LLᵖˢ: of mᵗ Iacobb ffarmoᵘʳ of yᵉ Impost of Tobacco who by color of a much latter Graunt from his Maᵗᵉ demaundeth of them an other vjᵈ the pound vppon their Tobacco contrary to his Maᵗ: most gracious Graunt, and wᶜʰ allso itt is not possible that poore Comodity can beare. They humbly therfore offer to yoᵘʳ LLᵖˢ: Consideraton wheras for the support and increase of that Plantaton to draw on the Collony more cheerfully to apply their labour, they have erected here a Society of pticuler Adventureᵐ for Traffique wᵗʰ them of Virginia in a loynt Stocke for dyvers years commonly called the Magazine, and have contracted with yᵉ people ther, as for other Comodities so pticularly to give them iijᵈ a pound for Tobacco, by vertue of wᶜʰ Contracts a great multitud of people have lately beene drawne to remove thither, and not soe fewe as one Thowsand Personns are providinge to goe and Plant there in the Springe approching, that if to that iijᵈ be added this 12ᵈ demaunded by the ffarmoᵘʳ together wᵗʰ other charges of ffraight Cᵗ itt will exceed the vttermost vallew wᶜʰ att this day the Tobacco can be sould for, and consequentlie must needs dissolve this Traffique established. And they further Complaine to yoᵘʳ LLᵖˢ: of mᵗ Iacobb that wheras this Company for the vphoulding of the said Traffique sett out in September was Twelue moneth a Ship to Virginia for the bringinge home of the Comodities as itt were the Harvest of that yeare, wherby the people there are to be maynteyned wᵗʰ clothinge and necessary Implements. DECEMBER 16, 1619

The Company here quickned with hope of proffite by traffique and by this mutuall negotiation his Ma[jes]ties Customs advanced: And accordingly in June last their Ship returned and brought home Twenty thousand pound weight of Tobacco for which besides the Marchandize bartered with them there they are to discharge here above Eight hundred pounds of Bills of Exchange, And upon returne of their Ship they brought their goods into the Custome house as they were required that they might be weighed and the Custome answered for the same which they were most willinge and redy to discharge, Mr. Iacobb of his owne authority interupted the weyinge of their Tobacco and forbad farther proceeding vnless that impost of vj* a pound were also paid unto him. Whereupon they flyinge to your Lordships for releife obteyned your hono[ra]ble Letter to Mr. Iacobb to deliver their goods they entringe into bond to pay him whatsoever should appear to be his due, by your Lordships iudgment upon certificate from his Ma[jes]ties learned Councell, and within one moneth after it should be determyned, which order your Supplyants did offer him to pforme. But Mr. Iacobb refusinge to pforme your Lordships order and exactinge of them another bond, vizd to pay him his demaund att a certaine day vnless they procure in the meane time a discharge from your Lordships which they thought vnfitt to vndertake beinge not in their power to effect hath ever since now for the space of fower monneths and vpward Contrary to his Ma[jes]ties tres Pattents and your Lordships honorable Tres (an example vnheard of) forceably deteyninge their goods to their damage att least of £2500 partly by the impayringe therof in worth through dryinge and other corruption and partly by the Sale of price upon the Store of English Tobacco which hath since beene made. They further Complaine of Mr. Iacobb that whereas the Somer Ilands are yett free for two years and an halfe vnexpired of every Custome and Subsedie, Mr. Iacobb who standinge by his Officers at Plymouth hath caused 12° the pound to be exacted for their Tobacco, and bond to be entred for the payment therof on the Sixth of this monneth vnless your Lordships shalbe pleased in the meane time to discharge the same. In consideraton of which premises these Petitioners most humbly beseech your good Lordships that whereas they are now in treaty for the providing & settinge forth of two Ships imeadiately, the one to Virginia expresly for his Ma[jes]ties service, and the other to the Somer Ilands for the necessary fortefyinge and securinge of that place, And for as much as they dare not lett them Carry thither soe vnwellcome news, as in the particulars before sett downe And forasmuch also as the preparations for the transport of those 1000 Persons are now all att a stand waightinge upon the success of this present buisines that your Lordships of your accustomed goodness and favor toward this Plantacon, and to preserve...

Capt Argoll de- Captaine Argoll vppon his owne desire to answere to such Crymes as are imputed to him in the time of his Gouernment hath been sundry times summoned to meete the Councell att Southampton house where haveinge sett many daies, Mr Thier now presented the passage of their seuerall proceedings with him, devydinge his charge into three partes. 1: His Offences in matter of State, 2: The Depredacon and spoile of the publique wᵗʰ other offences to the Company and Councell and 3: his oppression there of the Collony in generall and sundry pticularr men. To the Two first Mr Thier vppon the desyre of the Counsell was content to collect the falts, and sett downe in Articles the greivances of the Company because the said Capᵗ Argoll desyred to answere every pointe in writinge. Butt the third of the opression of the people haveinge no affinitie wᵗʰ the two other partes may be answered by themselvs when Certificate shalbe returned from thence of the same hee haveinge answered to the 4 firste Articles of Matter of State, The buisines to be The second parte of depradacon was deliuered vnto him in Eight Articles by Mr Thier earnestly desyringe the Courte (as the Councell thinke it Convenyent) that the prosecutinge herof might be taken outt of his hands, and referred accordinge to the Councell order vnto a Lawyer and a Marchaunt to solicite the Companies cause against him: And allso Capᵗ Argoll desyred that in respect hee was no great Scholler that hee might have liberty to entertaine Councell to defend his Cause: Soe the Courte for the Company have now made choyse of Mr Edward Harbert for the Lawyere and Mr Tho: Keightley for the Marchant agreeinge that all the writings and evidences shall be putt into their hands, And that the Thier and Councell shall be indges of the buisines, Mr Deputy promisinge to enforme and ease them as much as hee cann, allowinge allso of Capᵗ Argoll request.

Whereupon hee made a second that in regard Sir Thomas Smith was then there, and may say some thinge to some orders which was given him, that this busines might be heard att his house, which Mr. Threr said hee would not gainesay, whensoever the matter were handled to the knowledge of Sr. Tho: Smith, and the rather for that the firste moveinge against Capt. Argoll proceeded from Sr. Thomas Smith, and Mr. Alderman Johnson, with some other as appeareth both by their letters to Capt. Argoll himselfe of the 30 of August 1618, as also by their other tres to the Lord Lawarr at the same time, wherein they charge him with all or most of the said Crymes, & that in verie sharpe sorte; requiringe the Lord Lawarr to send him home to his answere to sequestre his goods there and to restore to the publique all such Cattle as hee had alyenated without lawfull warrant.

Whereas the last Court agreed to give vnto my Lord of London's Register for his paines in their Collections the some of xx poundes formerly promised Mr. Threr informed that his Lordship hearing thereof was not well pleased therewith and would not assent that any part of the 1000 li which hee had sent in should be diminished: As also that accordinge to the Archbishop of Yorke's desyre hee had sent him 200 new breif for Collection.

The Councell meetinge accordinge to the referrence in the last Court and perusinge the tres Pattents grew to this Conclusion that by the lycense of the said Councell it might be lawfull for either of the said Collonies to fish within the liberties the one of the other but since some of the Northerne Collony flyinge from that agreement pretend to Consider better of it before they will give answere thereunto. Howsoever the Councell haveinge occasion to pursue it uppon the Motion of Mr. Threr have given lycence under their seale unto the Society of Smiths hundred to goe a fishinge which Seale was this day in open Courte and by the allowance thereof affixed to their saide Lycense, as also to a Duplicate of the same.

494:
The motion approved of and the drawing of it referred to Mr. Thier & Dr. Winstone. Mr. Keightley's report touching the Magazine Account. Mr. Thier moved for 3 things to be considered of:

286 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY

The name of the Auditor who by one assent had approved thereof that a Publication might be set out in print. In the first part to set down the names in Alphabetical order of every Adventurer and their several Sums Adventured that thereby all may take notice of their sums brought in, and be summoned to come in for their Land proportionable thereunto, before the best were possessed by new Adventurers or Planters which might be also a means of a speedy increase and of the Plantation. And in the second part to confute such scandalous reports as have beene divulged of Virginia by the Justification of the Inhabitants there, which motion was generally approved by the Court referring the drawing of the said Publication to Mr. Thier & Dr. Winstone.

Mr. Thomas Keightley being formerly amongst others chosen an Auditor for the Magazine Accompt, now reported that although the Court took some distaste at Mr. Essington touching the same, yet he and the rest appointed with him having Audited it never found books in better order nor Accompts better kept, for not four pennyworth of goods is sent but is orderly set down, marveling that as it appears there should be 2000 & odd pounds owing to the Adventurers and they continue indebted 1000 pounds to the Chamber of London besides—5200 and odd pounds worth of goods remaining in the Magazine as it cost the first penny here: Whereupon it was moved by Mr. Thier that three points might be considered: 1: The sale of the Tobacco 2: Concerning those difficulties that are found in the Accompt mentioned by Mr. Keightley: 3: whether to proceed with the Magazine or dissolve it. For the first Mr. Bearblock, Mr. Caninge, and Mr. Smith are entreated to go to Sir John Wolstenholme to know when he holds it convenient to make Sale of it, and accordingly order shall be given for the Adventurers meeting.

The calling of this Mr. Thier signified that the cause of this extraordinary Courte was to understand their resolutions, about a matter recommended to them from his Ma'tie: by reason of the Maister of the Wardes, whether the Company would farme the impost of Tobacco or any part thereof at Eight Thousand pounds per Anni and pay 12d a pound for Custome of their Tobacco, it having been thought convenient to raise the Custome upon Tobacco to that Rate for that some Spanish Tobacco hath beene sold at Twenty Shillings per pound of which 12d: 6d: was to be paid to the farmers of the Imposte and 6d to the farmers of the Custome.

After some disputation it was answered that the King had granted them their Pattent under the broad Seale upon good grounds, to pay the King in his tres onely five per Cent: and no more which Prevyledge they could not give away nor betray without great breach of duty, as also the certaine hazard of the whole Plantation, And this point was stood so resolutely upon that being put to the question it was confirmed by all the hands no one dissenting.

And whereas some desired that in handling of this business they would have cleared the garbling of their Tobacco, which is expected shortly to be imposed upon them by the Patentees thereof: It was answered that it was not a thing pertinent to this business, as also that in the last Court it was spoken of but not concluded as thinking it unseasonable to goe about preventing of that which yet was not demanded, and in right could not be imposed on the Company whose goods are free from all impositions and Taxes. Mr. Thier and Mr. Deputy being yesterday with the Lo: Maior, Reported that he informed them, the Cittie had agreed to provide one hundred Children for Virginia, and to allow the Company five pound apeece three pounds towards their passage and forty shillings for Apparel, desiring Mr. Thier to deliver in writing the Conditions the Company will perform which he hath promised to doe to morrow: And further did demand what land they should have in lieu of their Transportation, who answered that they were not to have any, but after the expiration of their Apprenticeship, they were to be Tenants to the Common Land, but in regard the Cittie beareth the half charge of their transportation he thought the Court would allow them 25 Acres apeece of every each one of them, which for the present his Lor': seemed to be satisfied therewith. Touchinge the fowerth poynt matter of Trade, Mr. Treasuror acquainted the Courte, that the Magazine had now voluntarylie dissolved Her selfe, wth provision graunted for their goods remayning in Virginia so that now matter of Trade was free and open for all men wth that provision. Sr. your Charitable endeavours for Virginia hath made you a father wee a favourer of those good workes which although heretofore hath come neer to their birth yett for want of strength could never be delivered, (envy & division dashinge these younglings even in the wombe) vntill your helpfull hand with other honorable personages gave them both birth and beinge, for the better cherishinge of which good and pious worke seeinge many castinge guifts into the Treasury, I am encouraged to tender my poore mite and although I cannott with the Princes of Issaker bringe gould and silver Coveringe yett offer here what I cann, some Goats hayre necessary stuffe for the Lords Tabernacle, protestinge heer in my sinceritie without papisticall merritt or pharasaicall applause wishing from my part as much vnitie in your honorable yndertakinge as there is sinceritie in my designes, to the furtherance of which good worke, the Convertinge of Infidels to the fayth of Christe I promised by my good frends 500£ for the mayntenance of a Convenyent nomber of younge Indians taken att the age of Seaven years or younger & instructed in the readinge and ynderstandinge the principalls of Xian Religion vnto the Age of 12 years and then as occasion serveth to be trayned and brought vpp in some lawfull Trade with all humanitie and gentleness vntill the Age of one and Twenty years, and then to enioye like liberties and pryveledges with our native English in that place and for the better performance thereof you shall receave 50£ more to be delivered into the hands to two religious persons with securitie of payment who shall once every Quarter examine

Powell and Mr. John Smith being presented by their brother Provost Marshall of Middlesex to have grant of the Company 400 Acres of Land for fifty pounds Adventure betwixt them viz., One hundred lying in one parcel between the Sunken Marsh on the other side the River against James Citty Land, and Choapooks Creek, and one parcel of Marsh Land containing 300 Acres called Towritetoy Gou-Hogg Island, The Court held it inconvenient to grant Land in that kind, picked out by the Planters themselves not knowing who already may lay claim thereto or otherwise how necessary it may be for the publique; But Mr. Treasurer in regard of the good affection declared by their brother to the Companies service hath promised to write to the Governor that the said 400 Acres shall be well set out for them and to their Content with reason.

Upon good consideration of the scarcity of the Ministers that is this day remaining in Virginia having eleven Burroughs and not above five Ministers: Mr. Thier now commended to be considered by the Court the sending of one sufficient Divine to each of those Burroughs, for the Comfort of the souls of the inhabitants, by preaching and expounding the word of God unto them: And for the drawing and encouragement of such Preachers hereunto acquainted them of 100 Acres of Land according to former order to be allotted them which they being unable to manage alone are unwilling to go over, therefore because it may be prepared for them he would that there might be sent six men as Tenants to each of the 100 Acres of Glebe in the said Burroughs, in doing of which a yearly maintenance will be raised unto them of which the Company to bear the whole charge of them who shall be transported to the College Land, the Governor, and the Companies, and for those six that shall be sent by particular hundreds the Company for their better provocation thereunto shall furnish out three to each, upon condition that the particular Plantation make up the other three, which being put to the question was generally well allowed of, whereupon it was thought very expedient that my Lord of London should be solicited for the helping them with sufficient Ministers, as also such of the Company as without favour or affection could hear of any that were sincere and devout in that calling and were desirous to go, that they would acquaint the Court therewith that they may be entertained. Great mortality wch hath beene in Virginia about 300 of the Inhabitants haveinge dyed this last yeare and that Sr George Yeardley committes the former same error as formerly that hee dyrecteth all his letters to the Counsell and not any to the Company; But for ye people sent in the Bona Nova they are aryved in health are all liveinge & prosper well applyinge themselvs wth the rest accordinge to direction to the buildinge of houses tillinge of the ground plantinge Silkgrass: But forasmuch as the Courte was wholly ignorant of the State of the Colloney wch by the readinge of these [87] Letters now come they might be enformed of, therfore itt was ernestly moved by divers now present that they might be published to the Courte, but sundry of the Counsell thinkinge itt inconvenient, till a full number therof hadd first heard itt, wch was accounted seaven together, itt was therfore deferred till the next Courte and in the interim itt was agreed that the Counsell should be desyred to meete vppon Friday afternoone att Mr Thier's house att two of the Clocke, and that Capt Smith, and Capt Maddison then attend to make knowne their greivances wch they pretend done vnto them by Sr George Yeardley. And whereas Mr. Ferrar Deputy sent out the Garland to the service of the Company with 45 men of his and his Associates to be left in Virginia for the preparing and making ready of business against the Spring, intending together with his Associates to have sent divers others for the setting up of Iron Works; as also that the Council hath sent sundry letters by Wye, master of the said Ship, now forasmuch as he was appointed to touch at the Summer Islands and leave some men there and so proceed, he notwithstanding contrary to their directions and as he was bound by Charter party, finding that extraordinary gain would redound unto him by the great quantity of Tobacco which there was ready to come for England, diverted his Course from Virginia, left the men with their provisions in the Somer Islands, and what is become of the Letters it is uncertain, he being required since his Coming home at a Summer Island Court, to bring them to Mr. Treasurer and hath not yet performed it. And forasmuch as upon the motion of Mr. Ferrar in the last Summer Islands Court it was there ordered that his wages should be deposited till the differences betwixt them were ended, he thereupon hath annihilated the same by repairing to the Admiralty and by putting in bail to answer his Action he shall enter against him in respect whereof and in consideration of the great wrong and prejudice hereby falleth to the Company, (It was agreed being put to the question) that the said Company shall join with Mr. Ferrar in the suit against him, and to that end to entertain a Proctor, and Advocate and have entreated for the Company Dr. Winstone and Mr. Berblock to follow it for them, and for the defraying of the Charge have entreated Mr. Thier to disburse upon warrant what shall be needful.

The reading of the general assembly in Virginia being yet to read together with a letter which Mr. Yeardley desireth may be read for the clearing of his Brother Sir George Yeardley because it was held inconvenient to spend an ordinary Court therewith, it was ordered that Monday next in the afternoon be appointed for the purpose.

Mr. Aliano Lupo to Vppon the request of Stephen Sparrow itt was agreed yt Mr. Aliano Lupo who haveinge beene a planter in Virginia for 9 years past & there continuinge shalbe made free and have the proporconable rate of one hundred Acres of Land alotted him like as to other Adventurers.

As allso that the saide Stephen Sparrow att his owne charge transported three men to Virginia for whom Wm. Webb received the monny as hee witnesseth vizd: Iohn Slater, and Iohn Powell in the George in October 1617 & Wm. Thisselton in the Wm: and Thomas, in August 1618, whervppon itt was agreed accordinge to his desire that for the said 3 men hee should have 150 Acres of Land.

Walter Eldred produced to the Courte yt will of Thomas Hodges in wch will hee hath given vnto the said Walter Eldred 3 single Shares of 12": 10° wch appearinge to the Courte he dyed wthout issue, as also

that by the said will hee was sole executor the Courte now gave allowance thereof and soe was admitted into this Societie. Wheras vppon the peticion of Agnes Nicholls mother to one Henry Seaman to Dauies who did goe the Voyadge to Virginia with the Lord Lawarr in 1616 and att six moneths after his landinge hee there dyed as by certificate from Samuell Tubman may appear, itt was agreed vppon the said peticion and certificate that Susan Hamond the only sister and heire of the saide Henry Dauies shall have the Land due vnto him vppon his personall adventure. Forasmuch as divers peticions are to be read and some other buisines to be performed before Departure of the Ship, itt was agreed that Munday afternoone next shalbe an extraordinary Courte.

PRESENT.

Mr. Thier. Mr. Robt. Smith. Mr. Edwarde. Sr. Io: Dauers. Mr. Tho: Gibbs Iunior. Mr. Briggs. Sr. Tho: Wroth. Mr. Wheatley. Mr. Bamforde. Sr. Jo: Wolstenholme. Mr. Keightley. Mr. Roberte. Mr. Io: Wroth. Mr. Palmer. Mr. Geo: Smith. Mr. Tho: Gibbes. Mr. Berblock. Mr. Meuerell. Mr. Wrote. Mr. Barnell. Mr. Sparrow. Mr. Herbert. Mr. Rogers. Mr. Newporte. Mr. Baldwin.

A Complainte in writinge beinge now presented by some of the Adventurers of Martin's Hundred, for redresse of some wrongs, pretended to be done them particularly by one Boyse entertained there to be a Bayly of their hundred who contrarie to Covenants hath forsaken their Plantation and settled himselfe elsewhere; Itt was agreed accordinge as they requested.
540: 332 RECORDS OF THE VIRGINIA COMPANY desired, that the saide writinge should be enclosed in the Companies Lre, with advice to the Gouernor to rectefie their Greivances and further them in their lawfull desires. The Companie tre to Mr. Thier reported that the Comittee appoynted in the last Courte for the drawinge a tre for the Companie to the Gouernor have mett and finished the principall pointes of the same, if the Courte shall allowe thereof, therin menGoninge of two very sufficient and able men who are Deputies to goe as Deputies for the Companie and to take charge of two particular governmente under Sr. George Yeardley for menaginge and orderinge two parts of the publique Land, and tenante, the one for the Colledge, and one for that have dealt Mr. George Thorpe a gentleman of his Ma'ties pryvie Chamber, and one of his Councell for Virginia, who hath promised with all diligence to have exceedinge care thereof, the other of like sufficiencie but yett to be namelesse to have charge of the publique Land and Tenante sett out in the Burroughe, which wilbe no otherwise chargeable to the Companie then for the present, allotinge them of Land and allowinge them Tenante therevnto, And wheras Sr. George Yeardley offereth to serve the Companie gratis, the Companie hould itt not requisite to accept of his offer but rather to dispose some part of his liberallitie another wayle that therfore hee, (as they intend hereafter to covenant with such as shall succeed him hereafter) shall leave on the Governor's Land as many Tenante at the expiration of his Goverment as hee findeth or went with him at his entrance or afterwards shalbe sent vnto him. And wheras Capt. Argoll in the time of his suspension from the place in Virginia refer. Of Admirall authorysed, Abraham Peirsey the Cape marchant to be his Deputy or Vice Admirall which hee could not doe till by his cleeringe hee had frustrated the said suspension, Therfore the Comittee held itt fitt that the execution of that Office should be referred to the Gouernor and Counsell of State and to such vnder them as they shall appointe. And forasmuch as the Gouernor and Counsell there have allowed of certaine fees to be due vnto the Secretary by his place and sent itt hither for confirmation, the Comittee first and now the Courte pervsinge the same found them so oppressive that they found them so intolerable.

intollerable, & therefore held it convenyent that hee should have no fees att all but that the Companie would allowe him certaine Land and Tenements, and so to live vppon that but for his Clarke to allow him 6d or 4d in the Crowne there sett downe wch belonginge to the lawes of government, and magistracie to be there established is referred thereto [96] And likewise whereas a Complainte is made of the Cape Marchant by the Planters of double and treble rates sett vppon the goods contrarie to the Adventurers order that therefore the Governor and Counsell be authorized to make him produce his writings and Invoyces to examine whether hee hath dealt fairely or no and returne information to the Company. Hee also signified that Mr. George Yeardley desyred for his better direction the laws for Government and Magistracie wch although a Comittee was long since Chosen for the same yett by reason of other busines of maine consequents they have not proceeded therwith, requesting that now when all the Ships are gone and other busines settled they would graunt him so much libertie for his refreshinge as to retire himselfe for 3 or 4 week into the country in wch time hee would spend his studies in collectinge and framynge such lawes as may agree soe neer as may be to the Lawes of this Realme and his Maᵗᵉˢ instructions from wch if hee swerve in any thinge itt shall not passe till the kinge have approved therof: Itt beinge not fitt yt his Maᵗᵉˢ subiects should be governed by any other lawes then by such as shall receave influence of life from his Maᵗᵉˢ wheryppon wth many thanks for his care his request was graunted. Itt was informed yt the Lady Lawarr desyred yt 25 Shares adventure might be deducted outt of her Shares, and passed to Anthony Browne who intendeth to goe to Virginia and plant them wch the Courte allowed. The Governor to be authorised to examine yt Cape Marchant's writings & Invoyces. Other Additions to ye Treasurer referred to be performed by ye Comittee & to be signed. A petition read from Elizabeth Pearcy referred to the Adventurers of the Magazine. Frauncis Baldwins Petition being read it was agreed should be commended to the Gouernor in the tre from the Company. Whereas one Bartholemew Lawton was transported in ye Bona Nova to Virginia to remain a Tenant there, one Mr. Deverell made suit that he might be freed from that place and made free, and to that end would pay the charges the Company was at in sending him, and send him a man or two to work for him, unto which he was answered that his offer would not serve the turn but if he will send in his stead one approved to be sufficient and that will perform his Covenant his request by that means might be obtained and not otherwise wherewith he seemed satisfied. AN VNPERFECT COURTE HELD FOR VIRGINIA AT Sr. Edwin Sandys HOUSE YE viijth OF APRILL 1620.

PRESENT Mr. Treasurer. Mr. Keightley. Mr. Eyres. Mr. Tho: Wroth. Mr. Palmer. Mr. Brigs. Mr. Gibbes. Mr. Berblock. Mr. Arundle. Mr. Wrote. Mr. Cranmer. Mr. Newporte. Mr. Reighnolde. Mr. Palauicine. Mr. Ro: Smith.

A tre being read from Mr. Iames of Plymouth directed to Mr. Deputy signifying that one Spark should dewtiskke §divulge§ imputation of ye Countrie and Gouernment of Virginia falsely reporting that 900 men are dead this year, and that the people are used with
543:
APRIL 8, 1620

more slavery then if they were vnder the Turke, therefore for the curbing of his turbulent spirit, it was agreed that a Letter in the name of the Court should be written to the Maior of Plymouth to examine and learne vppon what ground hee should speake soe falsely and accordingly to certifie the Company that it may be followed with Iustice and equitie. Intelligence was given that Mr. Nicholas Ferrar the elder being translated from this life into a better, had by his will bequeathed 300 li towards the converting of Infidels' Children in Virginia to be paid vnto Sr. Edwin Sandys and Mr. Jo: Ferrar at such time as vppon Certificate from thence ten of the said Infidels' Children shalbe placed in the Colledge to be then disposed by the said Sr. Edwin Sandys and Jo: Ferrar according to the true intent of his said will, and that in the meane, till that were performed hee hath tyed his executors to pay 8 per Cent for the same vnto 3 seuerall honest men in Virginia (such as the said Sr. Edwin Sandys and John Ferrar shall approve of) of good life and fame that will vndertake each of them to bringe vpp one of the said Children in the grounds of Christian religion that is to say 8 li yearely apeece. An vnknowne person hath also given 10 li for some good vses in Virginia. Wheras Mr. Thier made knowne that notwithstanding the great deal of monny hee hath paid vppon old debts yet there remayneth something still to pay which chiefly is prizes due to Adventurers vppon the great standinge Lottery therefore moved that Mr. Wroth who hath taken a great deale of paines therein, and thereby gayned much experience that hee would examine what is due and to whome that the same may be discharged and that Mr. Brigs when hee is desyred may lend him his assistance. 

And forasmuch as George Berkleys widdow demaundeth as is formerly exprest a debt pretended due vnto her husband of 400 li which is...

The Auditor to examine what is due - 8 years olde, hee desyreth that some course may be taken for the true examination thereof that it be truly knowne that the Complainte thereupon is indebted or if parte of it hath beene satisfied, which was desyred that the old Auditor would take that paines as most proper unto them, And all the Officers of the Company: when they are requyred shall attend and beinge given to vnderstand that shee had sundry writings that might give more light unto the matter Mr. Briggs was desyred to peruse the same, and when hee had so done present his opinion to the Auditor.

Also hee signified that haveinge perused the Acts of the generall assembly hee found them in their greatest part to be very well and iudicially carryed & performed but because they are to be ratifyed by a great and generall Courte therfore hee hath written unto them that till then they cannot be confirmed in the meane time hee moved that a select Comittee of choyce men might be appoynted to drawe them into head and to ripen the buisines that it might be in a readinesse against the saide Courte.

Whereupon it was held requisite that accordingly 4 of the Councell & 4 of the generallytie should be chosen for the effectinge thereof which beinge well allowed, the Councell was nominated, Sr. John Dauers, Mr. Thomas Gibbes, Mr. Brooke, and Mr. Deputy, of the generallytie Mr. Sr. Thomas Wroth, Mr. Samuell Wrote, Mr. Berblock & Mr. Cranmer or so many of the Company as please, who are entreated to meete at Mr. Deputies upon Wednesday sevennight at 8 of the clock in the forenoone and then to agree when to meete and as ofte as they please.

And whereas 2 Complaints of wronge pretended to be done them by Sr. George Yeardley hath beene heard before the Counsell the one of Capt. Madison & the other of Captaine Powell whereof the one upon examination did manifestly appeare to be spleene and the other was upon title of Land notwithstandinge upon the motion of Mr. Téer it is ordered that a tre from the Company: shalbe written to Mr. Thorpe &c.

Counsell of State and therein inclose their said Complaint that they may examine the truth thereof and upon certificate from thence they may accordingly proceed to right either part according to equitie. [99] A Charter party by the Companies order being sealed by Mr. Tier: The Charter party to pay 600£ to some named by Captain Thompson within 14 days after Certificate of the Jonathan's safe arrival at James City and to be cancelled and landed her Passengers goods upon request now of the Owners that he would please that that said Charter party might be cancelled the money being by right to be paid unto them the Owners and not to him, and that he would seal another for paying thereof Accordingly unto them, the Court approving of it and desiring him thereunto he was content to seal it being first cancelled.
